review_title: I am a full time student here at Wells College
pros: The small class sizes give students the opportunity to ask questions, have a discussion in class, and get all the attention they need from the professors.  This College offers a variety of campus jobs and work study opportunities. Free transportation to nearby cities. Free weekly trips around Ny State (Festivals, Sight seeing, etc..)
cons: Can't think of any negatives. I love this school!!

pros: Gorgeous setting on lake with ivy-covered, historic buildings. Access to Ithaca and Cornell University. Minimal bureaucracy because of small size. Tight community of good, helpful people. Good place to break into a career, learn many aspects of a job and move on! Loyal alumnae.
cons: This school is perpetually on the brink of financial collapse. Every summer there is a cash flow problem/budget freeze because the school has to wait for new tuition revenue. A once-healthy endowment is now nearly depleted. Faculty salaries have stagnated since 2008, were reduced and restored, but retirement benefit was nearly eliminated. Tuition is more than $40k, but the college attracts mostly weak students who didn't get into better schools, so academic rigor has eroded. School is tied to unprofitable auxiliary businesses (Aurora Inn and related properties) that only make the overall financial situation worse. Winters in the Finger Lakes are brutal!

review_title: Nice place to lose a few years
job_title: Network Services Technician in Aurora, NY
pros: It's a small school so there is an opportunity to keep many skills current.  The size allows using enterprise tools while still being able to deal with each user individually.
cons: It's a small liberal arts college that is undergoing severe financial stress.  Facing declining market share and a depleted endowment, aging infrastructure and increasing employee turnover, it decided to go co-ed.  The PR bump was helpful for several years.  However, it's now old news.  It now faces the problem of finding another way of defining it's uniqueness.

pros: Excellent people to work with and a wonderful environment. Freedom to choose your own hours. Megan Riedl, my supervisor, is a wonderful boss, fair, fun, and excellent at delegating to the tutors and study group leaders underneath her.
cons: You are limited in the amount of hours you are able to work due to the work-study student employment program. You also can only work one student employment job, and therefore cannot use multiple jobs to increase the amount of work hours you can get.

pros:
- Wells is a great community of people who genuinely care about their students and each other
- As a small institution, there are lots of opportunities to work on cross-functional teams 
- The location is absolutely beautiful
cons:
- Upper leadership didn't always take staff concerns seriously
- Small teams mean everyone wears a lot of hats
- There is a distinct sense that the history of the school and its present/future are sometimes at odds

pros: Worked Closely with the teaching staff, access to studio is unlimited, access to additional materials, heavy hand in studio operations
cons: I found it to be ideal for an art student

pros: Small college, beautiful location, friendly students
cons: Poor salary, low morale, lack of nearby housing for faculty
